awd_titl_txt: Computation of Visual Context Information in the Primary Visual Cortex
awd_abstract_narration:
This proposal will increase our understanding of how the brain operates by revealing fundamental principles of information processing by the cerebral cortex, which is widely held to be the site of human conscious experience. Brains cannot be understood until their fundamental processing unit, the cortical column, is understood using the type of circuit level analysis proposed.  In addition, the interdisciplinary nature of the proposal will offer a unique opportunity to train young undergraduate students in both neuroscience and mathematics, disciplines that increasingly are synergistic in neuroscience.  Women and minority undergraduate students will be recruited to participate in the research and materials for educators of middle and high school students will be developed that deal with the neuroscience of our senses.

Cognitive functions such as thinking, perceiving and remembering, rely on the coordinated activity of neurons in the cerebral cortex. The cortical column is believed to be the functional unit of the cortex, thus understanding its circuitry and function is crucial to determine how the cortex works. The cortical column is composed of 6 interconnected layers, each with distinct function and connections. The goal of this application is to understand the role of this layered structure in cortical information processing.  Primary visual cortex (V1) will serve as the model system because its anatomy and functional properties are better known than those of any other cortical area. Electrode arrays will be used to record simultaneously across all layers the responses of populations of neurons in V1 to visual stimuli that are known to drive this area of cortex. This approach will reveal how the different layers of V1 are activated in time and space by different kinds of visual stimuli.  These methods will also allow an examination of the flow of visual information processing across layers of the cortex, a fundamental but heretofore understudied question. Finally, mathematical modeling will be used to understand how complex interactions between connections within a cortical column compute the neuronal responses specific to each layer.

por.por_cntn:
Project Outcomes

The goal of this proposal was to understand fundamental principles of information processing within the cortical column, the functional unit of the cerebral cortex consisting of six stacked and interconnected layers, each having specific input and output connections. Understanding how information is processed within this unit is crucial to understanding how the cortex works.

We asked how the different layers of a column in the primary visual cortex (V1) are activated in time and space by different kinds of visual stimuli. In particular, we focused on understanding how V1 layers integrate information across visual space. It is known that neurons in the visual cortex respond (i.e. generate electrical signals called spikes) only when visual stimuli are presented inside their receptive field (RF, i.e. the tiny region of visual space that the neuron looks at). Stimuli presented outside a neuron?s RF (in the RF surround) do not directly evoke spikes from the neuron, but can change (increase or reduce) its spiking response to stimuli simultaneously presented inside the RF. This phenomenon, called surround modulation, plays an important role in the visual perception of object contours. For example, imagine a neuron?s RF looking at a tiny part of a tree. This information is ambiguous, but integrating information from just outside its RF (from the near RF surround), the neuron can figure out that it is looking at tree part; integrating information beyond the near surround, i.e. from the far surround, allows the neuron to further figure out that the tree is embedded in a forest. Our aim was to identify the neural circuits that allow V1 neurons to integrate local and global spatial information from the surround, and which V1 layers process this information.

We used electrode arrays to record vertically neuronal activity (both the spiking and subthreshold responses) simultaneously from all layers of a V1 column in response to visual stimuli (shown on a computer monitor placed in front of the animal?s eyes) presented inside the recorded neurons? RF or at varying distances from the RF, in the RF surround. We measured the onset latency of responses across the different layers in response to these stimuli. Because different V1 layers receive different inputs, we reasoned that the inputs that are activated by a specific stimulus will, in turn, first activate those layers where they terminate. We found that stimuli in the RF, near or far surround activate different V1 layers. Specifically, stimuli presented inside the RF first activate layer 4, the V1 layer that receives subcortical inputs from the thalamus (the nucleus receiving inputs from the eye). Stimuli in the near surround first activate layers 2/3 and 5; long-range horizontal connections travel for several millimiters within these layers, and likely carry signals from the near surround to the neuron?s RF. Instead, a stimulus in the far surround first activate layers 1 and 6, i.e. the layers that receive feedback connections from higher cortical areas (V2, V3, V5), suggesting feedback carries signals from the far surround. These results demonstrate that different circuits and cortical layers are specialized in the processing of visual information in the RF, local and global surround.  See the video at: https://www.cell.com/cms/10.1016/j.neuron.2018.08.020/attachment/d12dc146-8af4-40a4-a1c4-5e73f6b6b038/mmc3.mp4

To further test directly the hypothesis that feedback connections are involved in the processing of far surround modulation, we selectively inactivated, using optogenetics, feedback neurons arising from cortical area V2 while recording neuronal responses in V1 to visual stimuli presented in the RF and surround. Our results indicate that feedback from V2 normally acts by reducing RF size (thus, increasing the visual system?s spatial resolution), affecting surround modulation (therefore facilitating the perception of object contours), and increasing V1 neuron?s response amplitude (thus, increasing sensitivity to visual stimulus features). In collaboration with mathematicians, we also used theoretical modeling to understand how interlaminar networks within a cortical column interact with long-range horizontal and feedback circuits to compute neuronal responses and surround modulation in different layers.

This project contributed to the training of 2 graduate, 5 undergraduate and 3 postdoctoral students. These trainees were immersed in a strongly collaborative environment encompassing neuroscience, mathematics and computer science, which contributed to their technical and intellectual interdisciplinary training. The graduate students and postdocs authored publications and presented their work at national conferences. One postdoc received an NIH K99 path-to-independence grant; another postdoc obtained a faculty position. The undergraduate students (3 women, 1 minority) were hired through existing institutional programs from the fields of bioengineering and compute science and exposed to Neuroscience. These students were trained in computer programming and data analysis, presented their work at national and local conferences, and some of them co-authored publications. Three of these students are currently enrolled in PhD programs in neuroscience at top institutions in the country. The project  also contributed to the development of new technologies, particularly optogenetics in large brained species.
